headline: Chef John's Buttermilk Fried Chicken
description: Buttermilk fried chicken that's crispy and tender. Whole chicken pieces are soaked in buttermilk, coated in seasoned flour, then fried until crisp.
name: Chef John's Buttermilk Fried Chicken

recipeInstructions.text: Toss chicken pieces, black pepper, salt, paprika, white pepper, rosemary, thyme, oregano, sage, and cayenne together in a large bowl.
Stir in buttermilk until chicken is evenly coated. Cover and refrigerate for 6 hours.
Combine flour, salt, paprika, cayenne, garlic powder, white pepper, and onion powder in a large shallow dish.
Remove chicken from buttermilk and dredge each piece in seasoned flour; shake off any excess and transfer to a plate.
Heat peanut oil in a large Dutch oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Add chicken pieces to the hot oil and fry for 10 minutes. Turn chicken pieces and fry for another 10 to15 minutes.
Transfer fried chicken to a cooling rack set over a paper towel-lined baking sheet. Let sit for 10 minutes before serving.

review.reviewBody: Easy taste was wonderful

I used boneless skinless chicken breasts and soaked them for 6 hours. I then cut them into 1/2" thick pieces and returned them to the buttermilk spice mix before flouring them. Initially I tried air frying one breast but the flour stuck quite badly to the rack. The next three were fried in a pan with about 3/8" of canola oil. My family loved these, even the air fried ones. We will be having the pan fried ones from now on. They are better than any we have eaten out!! Thanks Chef John. As my husband says - "You can never go wrong using a Chef John recipe!".
Amazing

My only changes are replacing a quarter of the flour with cornstarch and another quarter with baking powder; and doubling the cayenne pepper but subbing with Aleppo pepper because that‚Äôs what I have on hand. I also find that if I pour a little of the buttermilk marinade into the flour mixture and stir it up to make little lentil sized clumps, the crunch factor is through the roof. Really far better than anything I‚Äôve gotten out‚Ä¶ maybe ever? Thank you Chef John!
So the only thing I did different was fry the chicken in duck fat that I bought off Amazon. Really amazing.

Although I tried to keep my oil at the right temp, the outer skin still burned. I think the trick is to keep the pan covered to keep the heat even so the meat cooks evenly. Remove the lid at the end to crisp the skin.

End product is good, only things I took off stars for is -1 for the cooks note, it says to hold in 300 degree oil for 25 minutes? -1 for using peanut oil, it doesn't improve the quality of the finished product but is more expensive and more likely to have allergic reactions.

Cooked in a air fryer at 380 degrees for 25 minutes., turning once.

Added to my favorites and will make it again.

Great fried chicken. This was the first time I've tried to fry chicken and it came out beautifully. I did increase the seasonings x2 only because I like spicy food (tablespoon of cayenne pepper), and it turned out terrific. Thanks chef John!

I cooked this a little slower and checked internal temps just to be safe. But the breading really left something to be desired.
I would buy pre cut chicken next time. Life‚Äôs too short. It‚Äôs not hard to make and as long as you don‚Äôt cause a house fire it‚Äôs fun to make. I recommend it.

DELICIOUS! Moist, flavorful chicken with a tasty, crispy coating. WOW! We enjoyed this recipe so much, it's a keeper! Thank you very much for sharing, Chef John. We made the recipe exactly as written and it came out perfect. The chef's note on oil temperature was especially helpful the first time we made it.

Love this recipe! The only modifications I made: 1) used just chicken breasts, 2) used only 12oz of peanut oil to fry. Used four ‚ÄúCostco sized‚Äù chicken breasts, pounded them to flatten to about 1 inch thick before marinading. Fried each breast 2-3 minutes each side then put (carefully) on a baking sheet and baked 20 minutes at 400F.

Excellent! Chicken was very moist and great flavors. Easy dish to make

The spices are those with substantial flavor so I expected to find those flavors within the meat but that wasn‚Äôt the case.

A way to a woman's heart is through her stomach. This is the second time I have made this and it was perfect. The first time I waited for the canola oil to boil which it never did until I put the chicken in. Last time it was too hot and burned the chicken. Moist and tender, so flavorable and lick-your-fingers good!
tasted great
it was so juicy and tender

I rarely leave reviews but I want to say a BIG THANK YOU to Chef John as this is now one of many recipes of his that our family has made and absolutely loved. And this one too will be added to our ‚Äògo to‚Äô recipe list. I almost always make modifications to new recipes that I try out, but not with Chef John! He just nails every recipe down to a tee. This fried chicken was amazingly delicious, crunchy and perfectly seasoned. Thanks again!

this was my first time making fried chicken. with that being said it took me a while to figure out how to best to coat the chicken tenders to get a nice crust. my family enjoyed the recipe but i felt it was a bit bland. i will try this again and double up the spices.

This was delicious!! I even got my husband liking chicken again. Neither of us are big rosemary fans, but I think this is going to change my mind. We will be making this on a regular now.

Best Fried Chicken Ever !!! 

Frying Tips : Don't over crowd the pan. Always work in batches and let the oil come back to the proper temp before adding more chicken. After coating your chicken in the flower mixture, let it rest for a few minutes before you fry it. This will help keep your crust on nice and tight to the chicken.

Otherwise I made no changes to his recipe and it received rave remarks from everyone who tasted it. I also happen to have a soft spot for cold left over fried chicken, and this did NOT disappoint! The flavor is EXCELLENT! Chef John, you're awesome!

I have a Culinary Degree and I've got to admit, this chicken is better than mine. So this is now the only way I'll be making fried chicken!

I did a double dredge (dredged the chicken, dunked it back in the buttermilk, then dredged again) and let the chicken sit for a few minutes before frying. I deep fried for 12 minutes. SO crispy and juicy, my family said it was some of the best fried chicken they've ever had. I will so be doing this again!
Delicious, moist,, my family begs for this chicken

Super crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. However, I used the same temperature (I used a deep fryer so it maintains the correct temperature) and they came out super brown looking. They didn't taste burnt but they didn't look great. But they tasted great! So, if you're going for presentation and trying to impress someone, I would maybe go for a lower temperature for a longer time. My husband and I were the only ones to eat them, so they were good enough for us. I love Chef John and would love to cook with him someday, it's on my bucket list!
Used crushed red pepper instead of cayenne in buttermilk solution(out and improved) and let sit for 30 hours prior to dredging in flour. By far my favorite fried chicken
Great flavor- I do the frying in a Lodge cast iron wok outside on a propane camp burner.

I used boneless chicken thighs and boneless breasts cut in 3. I also switched out the flour for PC All purpose gluten free flour and fried in a frying pan on the stove top. Brought about 1 inch of oil to a boil and added chicken pieces turning them after about 10 minutes. Be very careful using this method, do not leave the pan of frying chicken unattended as oil can spatter out of the pan and cause fire if not monitored. Very tasty will make again
The flavor of his spices were good, next time I am going to add marjoram to it. The chicken stayed moist. I will make this over and over again.

Tasted great. I used 8 chicken thighs, double breaded them, and had just enough flour. I used Cajun seasoning instead of the sage, extra cayenne and marinated for 24 hours. Great recipe for chicken. Took some of the advice from reviews. Browned in peanut oil for 6-8 min then on rack in oven at 350 for 30 min. Nice and moist and crispy outside. Used 24 drumsticks , had enough to make another dozen pieces.
Way too peppery--but that's just me. Buttermilk marinade worked and chicken was moist and tasty. I fried in skillet instead of Dutch oven. Nice crunchy breadlng. Will try again with less pepper.

I added cornstarch into mix with floured herb mix and an egg to make a batter. I used an Italian herb mix and chervil. Lots of garlic salt and kosher salt. I used thighs so frying was not enough to cook them through. After frying I baked them for 20 minutes more with some oil in pan. Did not need any sauce. Plain was delicious. This recipe came out great!

very nice but I changed it up a bit, added cornstarch h for part of the total flour, for extra crispy and it worked well.

My hubby took a bite and said, "mmmm this might be better than KFC!!!" And he's a KFC lover! I'd definitely make this again and my kids loved this! I gave it 4 stars because as per a reviewers suggestion, I doubled the spices to go in the seasoned flour (except the salt) and it really needs that. It would be quite bland without it. Also I didn't have any buttermilk so made it with whole milk and vinegar and I just shallow fried it in a large pan which took about 16 minutes (used drumsticks). Edit: I fried some the next day but this time left the chicken dredged in flour for over an hour. The result was the crispy outside was falling off the chicken when it left to cool after frying. I won't be doing that again.
The recipe was perfect, although I did add some Frank‚Äôs Red Hot to the buttermilk for a little heat. The chicken was amazing!

Sweet Baby Jesus these were amazing! Anyone who enjoyed this should consider using Chef John's recipe for chicken fried steak, since the batter is different and IMO, only SLIGHTLY better than this one - mostly due to the fact that the baking soda used in the other one makes the breading a little more fluffy. Still, the flavor on these was amazing, and I didn't have the time to marinade in the buttermilk (only about 40 minutes). I really winged it since I had a lot more chicken than is listed in recipe. Also I had a couple of chicken breasts that I cut to be more or less the same size as the tenderloins. My suggestions/modifications: I could have used half the flour called for. I also cut back a little on the cayenne since my picky kids donna lika the spicy! :D

Also, I would pull the chicken out earlier than I did and that is suggested in recipe. Some of my pieces were extremely juicy, but most were just a BIT dry. Of course I used a blend of peanut and canola since I didn't have enough peanut, and put about 2-3 inches deep oil in a large, deep skillet (I don't own a dutch oven). Worked great and not very messy at all as I was expecting (grease was not everywhere). 

As always from CJ, an amazing recipe. Any recipes on here from him that aren't delicious? Crazy.
Definitely make it again...might just put a bit more spice in it but that‚Äôs just me
Quick, delicious and very easy. I‚Äôve never made any bread or worked with yeast before.
